title: Is a Deed in Lieu of Foreclosure considered a form of Foreclosure?
question: Our Client, a Corporation, has purchased a package of loans from a bank. We are selling one of the units that they took back with a Deed in Lieu of Foreclosure. The lender and HOA are questioning that this is a foreclosure.
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Residential property,Real estate buy and sell agreements,Property title,Foreclosure,Real estate and bankruptcy,Real estate,Homeowners' association,Deed in lieu of foreclosure
answers:
The whole idea about doing a deed in lieu of foreclosure is to avoid a sale through foreclosure. While it is not necessary that it is executed after foreclosure has commenced (through recording of notice of default), it usually occurs somewhere along the foreclosure process but before its completion.

You might want to ask them what they meant by "is this a foreclosure?". Also ask them why they ask this question.

To go one step further, while not typically a foreclosure, a lender taking back property under a deed in lieu ("DIL") very possibly will not want the ownership and debt to "merge" because the lender may need to foreclose out junior liens (like delinquent HOA assessments???) to pass clean title and avoid having to pay off pre-existing debts of the borrower. You really need to ascertain from your client what their intentions are, but you should not necessarily be the one providing a legal answer.

In most states it is not a foreclosure. As a result, no liens are divested. You take the land subject to all liens, inc HOA past due amounts.
